questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements regarding bones is false?

options.a: Osteocytes are the major cell type in mature bone
options.b: Collagen is synthesized in bone by osteoblasts
options.c: Bone mainly contains type 2 collagen fibres
options.d: Calcium phosphate is the major inorganic mineral

questions.explanation:
Bone mainly contains type 1 collagen fibres. Bones are made up of mineralized collagenous 
extracellular matrix around specialized cells. The extracellular matrix is composed of: • Organic component - around 30% of the organic matrix of bone is made up of collagen, mainly 
type 1 collagen. • Inorganic component - the major inorganic mineral in the bone matrix is calcium phosphate in 
the form of microcrystalline hydroxyapatite. The specialized cells are: • Osteoblasts - responsible for the synthesis, deposition, and mineralization of the bone 
matrix. Collagen is synthesized in bone by osteoblasts. Osteoblasts get embedded in the matrix to 
become osteocytes. • Osteocytes - major cell type of a mature bone and is distributed throughout the matrix. They 
have lost the ability to divide or to secrete new matrix. • Osteoclasts - responsible for the local removal of bone during bone growth and remodelling.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is a modified long bone?
questions.explanation:
The clavicle is a modified long bone, as it has a modified shaft and no medullary cavity. Long bones are classified as follows: • Typical long bones (see figure) have an elongated shaft (diaphysis) and two expanded ends 
(epiphysis). The shaft has a central medullary cavity and a nutrient foramen directed away from 
the growing end. e.g., humerus, ulna, radius, femur, tibia, and fibula. 1154 
Sold by @itachibot • Miniature long bones contain only one epiphysis. e.g., metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges. • Modified long bones have a modified shaft or ends, and no medullary cavity. e.g., clavicle. The following image shows a graphical illustration of a typical long bone:

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is not a sesamoid bone?
questions.explanation:
Os trigonum is an accessory bone, not a sesamoid bone. Accessory bones, also known as supernumerary bones are not always present. They may arise due 
to ununited epiphysis developed from extra ossification centres. Clinically, they may be mistaken 
for fractures. Examples of accessory bones: • Os trigonum - Uncommon accessory bone seen behind the talus. Also known as lateral tubercle 
of the talus. • Os vesalianum - Uncommon accessory bone located proximal to the fifth metatarsal and found 
within the peroneus brevis tendon. Also known as tuberosity of the fifth metatarsal. 1155 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is an example of a ■pneumatic bone?
questions.explanation:
The maxilla is a pneumatic bone. Pneumatic bones contain air-filled cavities, which make them light-weight. They also aid in the 
resonance of sound and act as air conditioning chambers for inspired air. e.g., maxilla, sphenoid, 
ethmoid, etc. Short bones: Carpal bones and tarsal bones Flat bones: Sternum, ribs, scapula, and bones of the skull vault Irregular bones: Hip bones, vertebra, and bones in the base of the skull. 1156 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following accurately describes fabella?
questions.explanation:
Fabella is a sesamoid bone. This term is used to describe a bone embedded within a tendon or a 
muscle. It is a variant of normal anatomy present in 10% to 30% of individuals. Fabella is found 
within the tendon of the lateral head of gastrocnemius, where it moves over the lateral femoral 
condyle. Important sesamoid bones: • Patella - largest sesamoid bone in the tendon of quadriceps femoris. • Pisiform - tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris. • Fabella - lateral head of the gastrocnemius. • Two sesamoid bones can be found in the first metacarpal within the tendons of flexor pollicis 
brevis and adductor pollicis. • Two sesamoid bones can be found in the first metatarsophalangeal articulation within the 
double tendon of flexor hallucis brevis. The X-ray image below depicts the fabella (marked with an arrow).

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following statements is true regarding long bones?

options.a: Cancellous bone is absent in the epiphysis
options.b: Cancellous bone is present in the outer cortex
options.c: Haversian system is absent in cancellous bone
options.d: Compact bone has lamellae arranged in a meshwork

questions.explanation:
The Haversian system is seen in compact bones, not cancellous bones. Based on their macroscopic structure, bones can be classified as compact and cancellous (spongy) 
bones. Compact bones are composed of cylindrical structural units called Haversian systems or 
osteons. Each Haversian system contains a central canal within which the small blood vessels, 
nerves, and endosteum are present. This canal is surrounded by multiple layers or lamellae of the 
calcified matrix containing type I collagen fibers. These canals communicate with each other by 
Volkmann's canal. 1157 
Sold by @itachibot The lamellae of the cancellous/spongy bone are arranged in a meshwork, and hence do not form 
Haversian systems. The diaphysis and outer cortex of long bones are predominantly made of compact bone, while the 
epiphysis and inner medulla are predominantly made of cancellous bone.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 16-year-old boy presented to your OPD with progressive swelling and worsening knee pain 
over the past 2 months. An X-ray reveals the following finding. Which of the following is true 
regarding the layer of bone involved? 1143 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Progenitor cells are present in the outer fibrous layer
options.c: It is continuous with the capsule of the joint
options.d: It is devoid of nerve supply

questions.explanation:
The given X-ray shows Codman's triangle, which is due to an irregular periosteal reaction 
(outermost layer), commonly seen in patients with osteosarcoma. The periosteum is a thick 
fibrous membrane that covers the outer surface of all bones, except at the joint surfaces and 
insertion points of tendons and ligaments (entheses). At the articular margin, the periosteum is 
continuous with the capsule of the joint. The periosteum has 2 layers: 1158 
Sold by @itachibot • The outer fibrous layer - contains fibroblasts. • The inner cambium layer (osteogenic layer) - contains progenitor cells that develop into 
osteoblasts. Periosteum gets nourishment from periosteal arteries. It has a rich nerve supply, which makes it 
the most sensitive part of the bone.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following structures do the Sharpey's fibers connect?
questions.explanation:
Sharpey's fibers are thick collagen fibers that connect the periosteum to the underlying bone. Sharpey's fibers are present in the bone and the teeth. • Bone - tether the periosteum to the underlying bone. • Teeth - connect the cementum to the periosteum of the alveolar bone (tooth socket). 1159 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following bones develops through intramembranous ossification?
questions.explanation:
Frontal bones undergo intramembranous ossification. Other bones listed have enchondral 
ossification. Based on their development, bones can be classified into 3 categories: • Membranous bones (dermal bones) are formed through intramembranous ossification. There is 
direct bone formation within highly vascular sheets or ‘membranes’ derived from mesenchymal 
condensations. e.g., bones of the facial skeleton including the frontal, lacrimal, zygomatic, and 
nasal bones. • Cartilaginous bones are formed by intra-cartilaginous (enchondral) ossification. Bone forms by 
ossification of preformed hyaline cartilage model. This is the main method of bone formation in 
the body. e.g., bones of limbs, vertebral column, and thoracic cage. • Membranocartilaginous bones ossify from both cartilage and mesenchymal condensation. 
e.g., clavicle, mandible, occipital bone, temporal bone, sphenoid bone, etc.

questions.question:
Question 11: The structure that the marked muscle in the gluteal region inserts into has  
 type of 
epiphysis?
questions.explanation:
The muscle marked in the image is the piriformis and its insertion is at the greater trochanter of 
the femur, which is an example of traction epiphysis. Traction epiphysis is nonarticular and does not transmit weight. They provide attachment to one 
or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis. Examples of traction epiphysis include 
greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus and greater and lesser trochanters of the femur.

questions.question:
Question 12: While assessing a child with short stature, the senior resident orders an X-ray to better 
evaluate the structure marked X in the radiograph. Which of the following is a true statement 
regarding this structure? 1145 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: It is made of elastic cartilage
options.b: It is supplied only by epiphyseal arteries
options.d: It is the site for enchondral ossification

questions.explanation:
The structure marked X in the radiograph is the epiphyseal plate. It is the site for enchondral 
ossification that is mainly responsible for the growth of long bones. The epiphyseal plate (growth plate) is a hyaline cartilage layer that separates the epiphysis from 
the metaphysis. It receives nourishment from both the epiphyseal and metaphyseal 
arteries. Fractures involving epiphyseal plates are known as Salter-Harris fractures. The growing ends of bones include: • Upper limb: Upper end of humerus, and lower ends of radius and ulna • Lower limb: Lower end of femur, and upper end of tibia

questions.question:
Question 13: 'The secondary ossification center that appears first, fuses last'. Which of the following bones 
violates this law?
questions.explanation:
1160 
Sold by @itachibot The fibula violates the law of ossification which states that the secondary ossification center that 
appears first is the last to fuse. The secondary ossification center at the lower end of the fibula appears before the ossification 
center of the upper end and fuses before the upper end. Ossification centers are of two types: • Primary centers appear before birth, usually during late embryonic or early fetal life (seventh 
week to the fourth month). They form the diaphysis. • Secondary centers usually appear after birth. They form the epiphysis.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following parts of the bone is not nourished by the nutrient artery?
questions.explanation:
The nutrient artery does not nourish the outer one-third of the cortex. The nutrient artery enters the bone shaft through the nutrient foramen and runs obliquely 
through the cortex. Nutrient arteries of the long bones are directed away from the dominant growing epiphysis as the 
growing bone might pull and rupture the artery. So the nutrient foramina are directed away from 
the growing end. The direction of the nutrient artery can be remembered by the axiom 'To the 
elbow, I go, from the knee I flee'. Blood supply of the Bon 
e Artery 
Regions supplied Nutrient artery 
Medullary cavity, inner 2/3 of the cortex, metaphysis Metaphyseal arteries 
Metaphysis and growth plate Epiphyseal arteries 
Epiphysis and growth plate Periosteal arteries 
Periosteum, outer 1/3 of the c 
ortex 1161 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: In which of the following parts of the bone are hairpin bends of end arteries abundantly 
present?
questions.explanation:
Hairpin bends of end arteries are seen abundantly in the metaphysis. The metaphysis is the portion of a long bone between the epiphysis and diaphysis. It is the zone of 
active growth and is highly vascular. Before epiphysial fusion, the metaphysis is richly supplied 
through end arteries that form 'hairpin' bends. The metaphysis is the most common location for osteomyelitis in children because the bacteria or 
emboli are easily trapped in the hairpin bends, thereby causing infection.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following statements regarding cartilage is false?
questions.explanation:
Articular cartilage despite being a type of hyaline cartilage lacks perichondrium. Cartilage is a connective tissue composed of cells (chondrocytes) and fibers (collagen or yellow 
elastic fibers). These are embedded in a firm, gel-like matrix that is rich in mucopolysaccharides. 
It is much more elastic than bone. Cartilage does not have blood vessels or lymphatics. 
Chondrocytes get their nutrition by diffusion. Cartilage has no nerves and is insensitive. There are three types of cartilages: • Hyaline cartilage • Elastic cartilage • Fibrocartilage Hyaline cartilage (except the subtype of articular cartilage) and elastic cartilage have 
perichondrium. Fibrocartilage does not have perichondrium. 1162 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following does not have yellow cartilage?
questions.explanation:
The septal nasal cartilage has hyaline cartilage and not yellow (elastic) cartilage. Elastic cartilage (or yellow cartilage) contains a matrix rich in fine yellow elastic fibers containing 
the protein elastin. It is present in: • Apices of arytenoid • Epiglottis • Corniculate cartilages • Cuneiform cartilages • Eustachian tube • Pinna (Auricle) • External auditory meatus

questions.question:
Question 18: What is the type of cartilage found in the structure marked X in the following radiograph? 1147 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The structure marked X is the pubic symphysis and the type of cartilage seen is fibrocartilage. Fibrocartilage contains a mixture of white fibrous tissue and cartilaginous tissue. This mix of 
fibrous and cartilaginous components make this tissue extremely tough and 
resilient. Fibrocartilage is present in the following sites: • Pubic symphysis • Manubriosternal joint • Articular discs of temporomandibular and sternoclavicular joints • Anulus fibrosus of intervertebral discs • Menisci of the knee • Acetabular labrum • Glenoid labrum • The lining of bony grooves for tendons

questions.question: Question 19: In which of the following cartilages is type I collagen predominantly seen?
questions.explanation:
Fibrocartilage predominantly contains type I collagen. Hyaline and elastic cartilages mainly 
contain type II collagen. Collag

questions.question: Question 20: Ligamentum flavum has high levels of:
questions.explanation:
Ligamentum flavum has high levels of elastin fibres. The ligamenta flava are a series of ligaments that connect the ventral parts of the laminae of 
adjacent vertebrae. They predominantly contain elastic tissue and form part of the posterior 
surface of the vertebral canal. The high content of elastin allows it to be stretched by 80% without 
damage. The ligamentum flava resist separation of the laminae in flexion and assist in extension 
back to the anatomical position.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is not a fibrous joint?
questions.explanation:
The symphysis is not a fibrous joint, but a secondary cartilaginous joint. Structural classification of joints is as follows: Type

questions.question: Question 22: What are synovial joints functionally classified as?
questions.explanation: Synovial joints are freely movable joints and therefore functionally classified as diarthrosis. Functional classification of joints: • Synarthroses - These are immovable. e.g., fibrous joints • Amphiarthroses - They are slightly mobile. e.g., cartilaginous joints • Diarthroses - These are freely mobile. e.g., synovial joints.

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following accurately describes a joint with three or more articular surfaces?
questions.explanation:
A joint with three or more articular surfaces is classified as a compound joint. Classification of joints based on the number of articulating surfaces: • Simple joints have 2 articulation surfaces. e.g., shoulder joint, hip joint. • Compound joints have 3 or more articulation surfaces. e.g., elbow joint, wrist joint. • Complex joints have an intra-articular disc between the articular surfaces which divides the joint 
space. e.g., temporomandibular joint, sternoclavicular joint.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following joints is known as a peg-and-socket joint?
questions.explanation:
Gomphosis (dentoalveolar syndesmosis) is a peg-and-socket joint between a tooth and its socket. Fibrous joints are joints where bones are joined together by fibrous tissue. They are further 
classified as sutures, syndesmosis, and gomphosis (see Table). The following image shows the types of fibrous joints: 1165 
Sold by @itachibot Classification of Fibrous joint

questions.question:
Question 25: 1149 
Sold by @itachibot What type of joint is an incudostapedial joint?
questions.explanation:
The incudostapedial joint is a ball and socket type of joint. In ball and socket type of joints, the articular surfaces include a globular head (male surface) 
fitting into a cup-shaped socket (female surface). These joints are multi-axial and movements 
occur around a number of axes. Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, medial rotation, lateral 
rotation, and circumduction, all occur quite freely. E.g., shoulder joint, hip joint, 1166 
Sold by @itachibot talocalcaneonavicular joint, and incudostapedial joint. Note: The other joint between the incus and malleus (incudomalleolar joint) is a saddle joint.

questions.question:
Question 26: A 47-year-old lady diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis presented to the clinic with the 
following deformity. The joint involved in this condition is an example of
questions.explanation:
The deformity shown is hallux valgus. This is caused due to an excessive lateral deviation at the 
first metatarsophalangeal joint. It is an example of an ellipsoid joint. Ellipsoid joints have an oval, convex (male) surface fitting into an elliptical concave (female) 
surface. They show biaxial movements such as flexion-extension, and abduction–adduction. A 
combination of these movements results in circumduction. Movement on the third axis is 
prevented due to the general articular shape. E.g., Wrist (radiocarpal) joint, atlanto-occipital joints, metacarpophalangeal joints, and 
metatarsophalangeal joints.

questions.question:
Question 27: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a  
type of joint.
questions.explanation:
The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint. • The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus. • The socket is formed by 3 structures: • Posterior surface of the navicular • Anterior articular surface of the calcaneus • Upper surface of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament). 1167 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 28: Forward and backward movements of the mandible that occur at the temporomandibular 
joint is called as 
and  
, respectively.
questions.explanation:
Forward and backward movement of the mandible that occurs at the temporomandibular joints 
are called as protraction and retraction, respectively. Protraction occurs when the lower jaw is 
pushed forward, while retraction pulls the lower jaw backward. Protraction and retraction also occur in the scapula. During protraction, the scapula is moved 
laterally and anteriorly along the chest wall, such as during rowing movements. Retraction is 
bringing scapula back to the original position after protraction. Option A: Opposition is the thumb movement that brings the tip of the thumb in contact with the 
tip of a finger. Returning the thumb to its anatomical position next to the index finger is called 
reposition. Option B: Excursion is the side to side movement of the mandible. Option D: Depression and elevation are downward and upward movements of the mandible (or 
scapula), respectively.

questions.question: Question 29: All of the following are rounded or irregular elevations of bones, except
questions.explanation:
The styloid process is a sharp elevation of bone. Bony elevations can be sharp or rounded: • Rounded or irregular elevations include a tubercle, tuberosity, epicondyle, malleolus, 
and trochanter. • Sharp elevations of bones include styloid process, spine, cornu (horn), and hamulus (hook-like). 1168 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 30: The type of joint marked in the image below is  
:

options.d: Muscle fibers are surrounded by perimysium

questions.explanation:
The joint marked in the above image is the costotransverse joint, which is a synovial type of joint. The various types of joints in the thoracic wall include: Sternocostal joints: These are the joints between the costal cartilages of the first seven ribs and the 
sternum. • The joint between the 1st costal cartilage and manubrium is a fibrocartilaginous joint 
(synarthrosis). • The joints between the 2nd to 7th costal cartilages and the sternum are synovial joints. The interchondral joint between the costal cartilages of the 9th and 10th ribs is never synovial and 
is usually absent. Type of Joint
